{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-100-02-A |Item_parent=Unusual acute and chronic headache in adults and children |Item_parent_short=Unusual acute and chronic headache in adults and children |Rank=A |Title=Know the main causes of headache requiring emergency treatment and their clinical presentation. |Description= brutal onset, progressive onset |Rubric=Identification of the emergency |Contributors= |Order=2}} - '''Two syndromes are absolute emergencies requiring systematic hospitalisation''' {| class="wikitable" |Meningitis syndrome |'''Diagnostic orientation''' |- |- ''''[[Headache SD-118|Headache]]'''': helmet-shaped, diffuse, intense, resistant to analgesics. Sudden onset, subacute or progressive depending on cause. - Vomiting SD-013|Vomiting]''' inconstant; effortless, in spurts and temporarily relieves the headache. - '''Photophobia''' - Shotgun attitude - Stiff neck, positive meningeal manoeuvres - [[Hyperthermia/fever SD-044|'''Elevated''''body temperature]] or normal |- Meningitis syndrome + '''[[Hyperthermia/fever SD-044|fever]] ='''' suspicion of infectious '''meningitis''' ('''item 151'''') è '''Immediate lumbar puncture without prior scan'''' - Meningeal syndrome + '''normal temperature''' + '''sudden''' onset = suspicion of ''''HSA (item 341)''' ''Immediate brain scan then LP if normal scan''
|- |'''Intracranial hypertension syndrome'''' |'''Diagnostic orientation''' |- |- ''''[[Headache SD-118|Headache]]''''': helmet-mounted, diffuse, intense, morning, exaggerated by cough/effort/decubitus, resistant to analgesics. Onset often gradual, sometimes sudden. - '''[[Vomiting SD-013|Vomiting]]'''': inconstant; effortless, in spurts and temporarily relieves the headache. - '''[[Coma and disorders of consciousness SD-028|Disorder of vigilance]]''': obnubilation, confusion, coma. - Horizontal [[Diplopia SD-143|Diplopia]] (uni or bilateral VI involvement) - Visual eclipses: transient, late bilateral loss of vision (due to severe papilloedema) - Bilateral papilloedema at the fundus - Infant: fontanel bulge, augmented PC |- ''Space-occupying process'': intracranial tumour (''item 299''), subdural haematoma, abscess - '''Hydrocephalus''' - Cerebral venous thrombosis è ''Emergency CT scan or MRI (without or with injection) è ''LP contraindicated BEFORE brain imaging but imperative AFTER normal brain imaging or imaging suggesting a meningeal process'' |} - '''Also refer to the emergency department any patient who presents''' ([[Headache SD-118|headache]]; [[Assessment and management of acute pain SD-259|assessment and management of acute pain]])''' :'''' o a "brutal" headache (maximum in less than an hour), or even a thunderclap headache (maximum intensity in less than a minute) => SAH until proven otherwise; o a headache that is ''recent or of recent aggravation'' (< 7 days) and ''unusual'' => HTIC until proven otherwise; o headache associated with ''[[Hyperthermia/fever SD-044|fever]]''' (in the absence of an obvious general cause such as a viral syndrome during an epidemic) => infectious meningitis; o headache associated with "neurological signs" (anisocoria, cranial nerves, central neurological deficit); o a headache suggestive of CO intoxication; o headache in the context of immunodepression. - The absence of any associated symptoms and a normal clinical examination do not rule out a secondary headache and should not delay further investigations if the headache is recent, unusual and persistent. [Reasoned request/prescription and choice of diagnostic test SD-178|(reasoned request/prescription and choice of diagnostic test)]] - Migraine sufferers often present with a severe attack. If the questioning is reliable and the patient recognises "his" usual migraine attack, investigations are not necessary and treatment will be given to relieve the attack. - Red flags in children: drop in school results; persistent unilateral localisation; epileptic seizures ([[Convulsions SD-120|convulsions]]); new-onset clumsiness; behavioural problems; change in staturo-ponderal curve; parental concern; age < 3 years (rare primary headaches); rapid increase in head circumference; murmur on auscultation of the fontanelle; recent strabismus or drop in visual acuity.

question.title: What is the immediate next step for a patient suspected of having infectious meningitis?
question.description: The patient presents with headache, vomiting, photophobia, and stiff neck, and has a fever.

option_a.title: Perform a lumbar puncture without prior imaging
option_a.description: This option is incorrect because it is not recommended to perform a lumbar puncture without prior imaging in cases of suspected meningitis.

option_b.title: Perform a brain scan and then a lumbar puncture
option_b.description: This option is correct because it is the recommended approach for a patient suspected of having meningitis, as it allows for the identification of a space-occupying process before performing a lumbar puncture.

option_c.title: Perform a lumbar puncture and then a brain scan
option_c.description: This option is incorrect because it is not the recommended approach, as it may delay the diagnosis of a space-occupying process.

option_d.title: Observe the patient and perform a lumbar puncture if symptoms worsen
option_d.description: This option is incorrect because it may delay the diagnosis and treatment of meningitis, which can lead to serious complications.

correct_option.title: Perform a brain scan and then a lumbar puncture
correct_option.description: This option is correct because it is the recommended approach for a patient suspected of having meningitis, as it allows for the identification of a space-occupying process before performing a lumbar puncture.
